instruction: What kinds of spectrum were used in the related study on predicting organic matter content in farmland surface soil?
Output: In the study on predicting organic matter content in farmland surface soil, visible and nir hyperspectral data were used.

instruction: What spectral feature processing methods were used to extract feature bands in the related study on predicting organic matter content in farmland surface soil?
Output: In the study, the spectral feature processing methods used to extract feature bands on predicting organic matter content in farmland surface soil were correlation coefficient and recursive feature elimination method.

instruction: What metric was chosen to evaluate the prediction performance of the Stacked Generalization Model (SGM) in predicting organic matter content?
Output: The metric chosen to evaluate the prediction performance of the Stacked Generalization Model (SGM) in predicting organic matter content is the decision coefficient (R-2), relative analysis error (RPD), mean absolute error(MAE) and root mean square error. The best result can reach R-2=0.819, RPD=2.256, MAE=1.742 and RMSE=2.308.

instruction: What machine learning models were used in the study on predicting organic matter content in farmland surface soil using VIS-NIR hyperspectral data?
Output: The machine learning models used in the study on predicting organic matter content in farmland surface soil using VIS-NIR hyperspectral data are Random Forest (RF), Gradient Boosting Decision Tree (GBDT), eXtreme Gradient Boosting (XGBoost), and Adaboost.

instruction: Can the stacked generalization prediction model using spectral information effectively estimate organic matter content in farmland soil surfaces, providing a rapid and stable method for detecting organic matter content in farmland soil surfaces?
Output: Yes, the stacked generalization prediction model using spectral information can effectively estimate organic matter content in farmland soil surfaces. It provides a rapid and stable method for detecting organic matter content in farmland soil surfaces. The model has shown good correlation between spectral information and organic matter content, with a maximum correlation of -0.611. Compared to other algorithms, the stacked generalization prediction model has higher decision coefficient (R-2) and lower relative analysis error (RPD), indicating its accuracy and stability. The mean absolute error (MAE) and root mean square error (RMSE) of the model are also lower than those of other algorithms, further demonstrating its effectiveness in estimating organic matter content in farmland soil surfaces.
